tei:publicationStmt.tei:authority: PRIN 2017 "Lingue e culture dell'Italia antica: linguistica storica e modelli digitali | Languages and Cultures of Ancient Italy. Historical Linguistics and Digital Models"

tei:msContents.tei:summary: Fragmentary building inscription, on a stone slab broken in two joining fragments, perhaps belonging to the epistyle of a column. Some editors only knew the second fragment of the inscription (see Antonini 1996). From Barrea, near Aufidena, AQ. Crawford, ImIt 2011 groups ItAnt Oscan 230 (= fragm. A), ItAnt Oscan 237 (= fragm. B) and ItAnt Oscan 233 (= fragm. C) togheter (see commentary).

tei:support.tei:objectType: stone slab the block is composed of two joining fragments, perhaps belonging to the epistyle of a column

tei:encodingDesc.tei:p: Marked-up according to the EpiDoc Guidelines

Photograph of the inscription ItAnt Oscan 230. The image is provided by the British Epigraphy Society.

tei:div.tei:p: [...] figlio di [ ]ius [...] figlio di Caius edili ??? il pronao (?) approvarono

tei:desc.tei:ref: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International license – (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0).

tei:div.tei:p: [...] son of [ ]ius [...] son of Caius aediles ??? the pronaos (?) passed them as completed

tei:desc.tei:ref: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 license.

tei:note.tei:p: The inscription was part, together with ItAnt Oscan 233 and ItAnt Oscan 237, of the Collection of Achille Graziani in Alvito, in which they were collected after belonging to Ferdinando di Loreto. According to Graziani 1938 , the inscriptions were found in the hunting lodge of Potito di Loreto in Barrea.

The correct find-spot is reported by Garrucci 1854 in the editio princeps. Afterwards, starting from Corssen 1862, some misunderstandings occurred concerning the finding place, which eventually propagated to successive publications.
The inscription is engraved on a limestone block composed of two joining fragments, perhaps belonging to the epistyle of a column.
The text records the construction of a building, including a peeslúm, by two aediles.

As Prosdocimi 1976: 835-848 correctly pointed out, pestlúm (ItAnt Oscan 11) and peeslúm are calques on the Gr. περίστυλον (see Logeion) referring to the inner area of the portico of the temple, i.e. 'pronaos' "e tale pronao è un peristilio" (p. 874). The same word appears as a loanword (perissty[leís), in ST Cm 3 from Avella. A different proposal by Rix 1976 suggest to interpret pestlúm < *ped-tlo-m 'podium' (see ImIt 2011: 1166 and Poccetti 1979: 37-40.

Crawford, ImIt 2011 groups the three texts from Barrea togheter. However, the material state of the inscriptions does not seem to authorize his hypothesis, since one of the inscriptions has been lost and the other two have no material joining points.
